abstract.p: Article describes indelible moment from 2006-7 theater season, performance of musicians in orchestra in show LoveMusik; photo (M)

block.p: As anyone who regularly attends musicals can attest, the sound of music on Broadway these days is often about as appealing as the throb of a jackhammer or the blare of a bus horn. Those distracting little microphones crawling like insects out of the hairlines of the performers are a bit of an eyesore, but what really sets the nerves on edge is the tidal wave of mushy, amplified sound that now seems to be the standard for Broadway musicals.

So the sheer loveliness of the playing in the pit of the Biltmore Theater, where ''LoveMusik'' is now in residence, was a caress that came with the force of a revelation. For many years the orchestrations of Jonathan Tunick have been integral to the artistry of musicals new and old. His collaborations with Stephen Sondheim are particularly notable, but the delicacy he has brought to the songs of this bio-musical about Kurt Weill and Lotte Lenya, with Michael Cerveris and Donna Murphy, surely ranks among his greatest achievements. (Mr. Tunick won Tony nominations for both ''LoveMusik'' and ''110 in the Shade'' this season.) More thankfully still, it was
amplified with a gentle hand by the sound designer Duncan Robert Edwards.
My ears, and those of every Weill admirer in the audience, are immensely grateful to all. Now if only something could be done about those lyric-obscuring German accents.
